review.title: Norm Monitoring under Partial Action Observability
review.abstract: In the context of using norms for controlling multi-agent systems, a vitally important question that has not yet been addressed in the literature is the development of mechanisms for monitoring norm compliance under partial action observability. This paper proposes the reconstruction of unobserved actions to tackle this problem. In particular, we formalise the problem of reconstructing unobserved actions, and propose an information model and algorithms for monitoring norms under partial action observability using two different processes for reconstructing unobserved actions. Our evaluation shows that reconstructing unobserved actions increases significantly the number of norm violations and fulfilments detected.
histories: Accepted at the IEEE Transaction on Cybernetics

metadata.title: Norm Monitoring under Partial Action Observability

sections.text: Index Terms Monitoring, Action Observability.I. INTRODUCTION Within the Multi-Agent System (MAS) area, norms are understood as a means of coordinating and regulating the activity of autonomous agents who interact in a particular social context. [19] However, the existence of autonomous agents capable of violating norms implies the development of standards control mechanisms that implement norms in agent societies. [21] Most of these proposals focus on providing efficient and scalable methods to monitor norms in dynamic agent societies, but they assume that all actions by agents are observable. However, this assumption is too strong because it is not necessarily true that all actions to be monitored can always be monitored. One reason for this is that the monitoring of actions normally incurs high costs.

sections.heading: II. PRELIMINARY DEFINITIONS
sections.text: This year, it is only a matter of time before an agreement is reached.

sections.heading: III. NM INFORMATION MODEL
sections.text: We assume that actions are deterministic, and that the current state develops from the performance of actions in only 11 years. NM's goal is to analyze a partial sequence of actions performed by agents and observers to detect violations of norms. Enforcement of norms is beyond the scope of this work, and we assume that as soon as the NM detects a violation of norms (vs. compliance), it applies the appropriate sanction (vs. reward). When the NM observes a sub-sequence of actions, it observes a sub-sequence of actions performed by agents, it has partial information about the state of the world. NM represents each sub-state of the world denounced by a partial deviation.

sections.heading: IV. NM ALGORITHMS
sections.text: Algorithm 1 contains the NM pseudo-code. At each step, the NM observes the actions of the agents and uses this information to update the current and previous partial states (lines 4-9). If all actions in the previous state were not observed, the NM performs the reconstruction function to reconstruct unnoticed actions (lines 11-14). Then, the CheckNorm function is executed to determine which standards in the previous state (line 15) according to definition 9 and 10. Note that the NM code can be executed while actions are performed without delay. With regard to the time cost of the algorithm executed by NMs, it is determined by the cost of the reconstruction function, the implementation of which (complete and approximate) is discussed below. sections.heading: 16: t← t+ 1
sections.text: This function calls the function search to search for the actions of the target agent (line 2), then checks for consistency according to definition 7 (lines 4-6) for all found solutions of the NM. Finally, consistent solutions are used to expand the series of observed actions and knowledge of the initial and final actions (lines 7-14), the time cost of this algorithm being given by the cost of the search function discussed below. Algorithm 3 contains the pseudo code of the recursive search function, which calculates all sequences of consistent actions performed by the agents that were not observed. It starts with verifying that there is at least one target agent (line 2). If so, it identifies all actions that may have been performed by a target agent (lines 3-4), an action may have been performed consistently according to the static properties, the domain knowledge, and the initial and final states executed.

sections.heading: V. EVALUATION
sections.text: This year, it is at an all-time high in the history of the European Union.

sections.heading: VI. RELATED WORK
sections.text: In fact, most people who are able, are able, are not able to determine for themselves what they want and what they want to do.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSION
sections.text: Our experiments show that both reconstruction processes detect more violations of standards than conventional monitoring approaches. An approximate reconstruction performs slightly worse than a complete reconstruction, while its calculation costs are much cheaper and therefore practicable. The reconstruction algorithms proposed in this paper can be applied to several areas that require monitoring; from normative MAS [31] to intrusion detection systems [16] to control systems [26] and intelligent monitoring systems [17]. As a future work, we plan to investigate area-based approximations that could further accelerate the reconstruction of measures.

Previous work on norms for regulating MAS proposed control mechanisms for norms to have an effective influence on agent behaviours [15].

These control mechanisms are classified into two main categories [15]: regimentation mechanisms, which make the violation of norms impossible; and enforcement mechanisms, which are applied after the detection of norm violations and fulfilments, reacting upon them.
